Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

eZUmTYABToqVbxZ8WaE4HQ.text: Amazing cakes and good coffee. The decoration it's really funny because there are elephants in everywhere. It's a nice and comfortable place. Always very busy specially full of Harry Potter fans who want to enjoy one of the places where this character was born.

utSBrsOk5OntzZv22y73NA.text: Famed for being the place where J K Rowlings wrote at least part of Harry Potter and that's about it!   If you are not a fan, all you'll find is decidedly average lunch cafe fare and probably the worst pie mash and gravy in Scotland.  As I mentioned above, it's redeeming quality is the Harry Potter fans - be sure to check out the restrooms

SQvbBt_-vOeR9i8WsBAgGg.text: Yep, the birthplace of Harry Potter, JK Rowling spent time in this cafe writing her first HP novel. It overlooks the cemetery in the back, with a view of a prep school which inspired Hogwarts.  There is also an old writing desk with a few drawers on the side - apparently if you pop it open, there will be paper and a pen for you to write. Some cool tidbits there, but as famous as this cafe got, I don't think the food was good though the space in the back is really nice.   I ordered a mallow delight, which was "hot chocolate with a marshmallow cream".  I guess I got that, but for 3.50, it was 3 packs of instant hot chocolate (Cadbury?) and marshmallows and topped with whipped cream. It was 1.50 more expensive than the regular, and incredibly sweet.   I also ordered the coconut blueberry cake, which I thought was dry, and I guess it was my slice probably but it didn't have any blueberries. I had to ask what it was, since I wasn't sure if it was a square sheet cake, or a brownie, or a bar. I kept getting the reply "uh it's coconut and blueberry..".  I can read, but is it a cake? A bar?  Anyway I thought my snack was a bit on the expensive side for something that didn't taste very good. I also felt silly paying 3.50 for packaged hot chocolate - at least put it in a fancy looking can so I think its something a bit nicer!    Maybe the other food is better, but I'm not really inclined to come back here to figure it out!

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Mallow delight, and coconut blueberry cake slice
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. View from the back of the cafe

srPU9hQOgdKW-sX1TZCsMA.text: I went here 3 times on my 3 day trip to Edinburgh ! It was that good! The food, service, and atmosphere was wonderful. I am also a huger Harry Potter fan so that helped. However, the atmosphere was relaxed and perfect for a cup of tea or a casual meal. It also wasn't to crowded in the evening and night time in which we went.  The orders: 1) veggie nachos - I felt their was too much chilli for the nachos but the portion was very large for one person and it was overall good. My friend got the smoked salmon and that was wonderful. 2) tea and apple pie - can't go wrong here just came here after a long second day in Edinburgh  3) haggis meal! - better then the haggis I got in a previous restaurant and the mast potatoes were amazing

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

cJUBJ0P7Zr5ekYs_arB5aQ.text: I literally just went to the bathroom here. The birthplace of Harry Potter? Of course I had to! First time I've ever left graffiti anywhere either. *please view photo of bathroom before judging, it's what you do here. Pretty awesome staff for having people like me from all over the world coming in just to go to the bathroom and see where J.K. wrote. It was like a pilgrimage of sorts. You have to go here if you're an HP fan.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. 3

pFRHL6Maa1cp_4CfrAT0fQ.text: Seeing the birthplace of Harry Potter is cool.  Otherwise, service is mediocre.  Felt as though they wanted to push tourists in and out resulting in people who appeared more like locals being given a full food menu, and tourists being given only a menu with cakes and scones.  Not to mention my scone was ridiculously dry and didn't seem fresh at all.  The bathroom is the coolest part because there's a ton of Harry Potter graffiti.  Worth a stop in if you're a True blue HP fan, but would not recommend if you're looking for actual food.

nLy8wu47J6rUo-oGKbMztA.text: Hm...what to say.   Well first off, it was very cool to be in a place that acted as a source of inspiration for such a wonderful writer. Personally, I'm not actually a "Potterhead". I more align with the "Twihards". But as a bookworm, I have absolute respect for both the series and the author, and so this spot was a no-brainer for our itinerary.   In terms of ambience, it's pretty packed at all hours of the day. We went for dinner, and though we didn't have to wait to be seated, the seating itself was in close quarters. There were tons of people, and that made for a very loud setting. There's a lot of Rowling memorabilia on the walls, and the bathrooms are absolutely filled with what I have coined "Potterhead Love Notes". I did not partake in the graffiti, but I can imagine that for a Potter Lover, this would be an awesome experience.   In my opinion, the food was delicious. But there were a couple others in my party that disagreed. Their menu is a little eclectic. I was more expecting...I don't know, whatever a cafe in Scotland would normally serve? But as you'll see with what we ordered, they had foods from many cultures.   I ordered the Tomato Bruschetta, the Soup of the Day which turned out to be Zucchini and Lentil, and the Elephant Treat for a drink. I loved them all. The bruschetta was fresh and refreshing. For any Americans traveling through the area, Scotland has very heavy food, as you might have noticed. So the light snack was really refreshing. The soup was also delicious. Very thick, and tasted almost like a zucchini chili - if that makes sense at all. And the drink was YUM. A perfect hot tottie after walking through the chilly Scottish weather for eight hours.   The Elephant Nachos were ordered as an appetizer to share. If you follow my reviews, you know that I'm originally from Southern California. I mention that because as Californians, we were quite impressed with the nachos. They were amazing. Very simple, but very tasty. And cheesy - which is the best part. And the guacamole was authentic!   The couple of people in my party that didn't enjoy their meals were the ones that ordered the lasagnas. They all agreed that it was much too cheesy and thick. None of them could finish even half of their portions because of the richness. Perhaps that's just our American tastes getting in the way, but if you don't enjoy heavy, rich food, this might not be the best option for you.   Speaking of portions - they're huge! We definitely over-ordered. I even tried to order small, but couldn't finish either of the options.   A Mocha and a Vanilla Latte were also ordered during the visit. Both were delicious, but I liked the latte best.   And finally, the service was decent. Since it was so busy, everyone was a bit preoccupied so there were moments in which we needed things but had no one to ask them for. But other than that, they were attentive when they could be, and that was much appreciated.   Definitely a cool experience. I'm sure this would be an amazing occasion for Harry Potter obsessed fans. I deem this an Edinburgh Must-Go.   Happy feasting!

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. I *heart* Dobby.
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. The entire bathroom looks like this. Every stall. Even the ceilings.
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Potterhead love notes.

f9Ss-xghIpxxC_47ku3Sog.text: Expensive for what you get really. Also, the waitress managed to spill hot tea in my friend's lap. Dont get me wrong, cakes and drinks as expected but their prices are cheeky so you can't help feeling they really cash in on JK's former custom. If you are a JK fan step inside or take your pic outside. If you want good value, go elsewhere.

kpLNVfRVhfQKoHw78paa7g.text: Crowded and noisy, the staff is way overworked and the service is terrible. Expect long waits to be seated, waited on and served. They ran out of potatoes (!!!) so we had to change our order. Errors made in order and bill had to be corrected. Food is mediocre. Prices, however, are low.   If you are not a Harry Potter fan there is no reason to go. If you are, there is nothing that will keep you away...

IxTpRT1jjjgel5dPZCGhDg.text: This afternoon I stopped by The Elephant House for a snack.  I had been looking forward to eating here since my trip to Scotland last year.  The expectation was far more satisfying than the reality.  It was sort of like being asked out by the most popular boy from your high school at your twenty-year reunion only to find out that he still works at the same movie theater and lives in his parent's basement.  From the moment I walked in, I felt unwelcome.  The hostess who sat me acted as if she were doing me a favor by letting me dine in her establishment.  As the restaurant was not particularly busy, I asked for a seat by the window.  Since I was by myself, the hostess insisted in seating me as far from the window as possible, in the middle of a through way.  After the third time one of the wait staff bumped into me, I moved to the other side of the table.  Almost immediately a mother and daughter were sat next to me, effectively boxing me into a corner where the only way out was to crawl under the table or scale the lady next to me.  I'm not sure why they were sat next to me when over half of the tables in the room were empty-- including several by the windows.    I ordered a glass of red wine and bowl of mixed olives.  A young waiter apologetically informed me that they only had black olives.  Very polite and personable, my brief interaction with him was the highlight of my entire experience.  My bill was brought before my food and drinks were delivered.  When the olives arrived, they looked as if someone had opened a jar of supermarket sliced olives, poured a bit of oil on them, and sprinkled a few herbs-- they tasted that way, as well.  Waxy and flavorless, don't waste your hard earned pounds on these.  The wine was substandard and overpriced.  I only managed a few sips before giving up.  The best part of my snack was the bottle of sparkling water that I could have purchased at the corner market for a fraction of the price.  When I enquired about paying my check, I was directed back to the front of the restaurant where I waited a good amount of time until someone came to the till.        Final Thoughts:  The view of Greyfriar's Cemetery and Edinburgh Castle from the back room is gorgeous.  If you can get a seat near the window, it would be worth the price of a cup of tea or a cappuccino.  If your goal is to writing the great Amer . . . er . . . Scottish novel, this is probably not the best place.  No WiFi (paid or free) and if you linger, you are unceremoniously glared at until you vacate your table.  Next-door at Patisserie Valerie or The Library Bar on the University of Edinburgh campus would be much better choices.

pbPRKvCRvn8QG2eXIUvD9w.text: Okay. Right, so here's something you need to know about me. I am a little tiny bit of a Harry Potter nerd. In school, I was "the Potter girl" for a reasonably long time. Therefore, as you can imagine, coming here is a bit of a sentimental thing.   That being said, I still have some criticisms. Firstly, well, it's too warm in here! Edinburgh outside was cold and I nearly fainted because it was so hot. The menu isn't signposted very well which is disappointing especially as you spend enough time in the queue waiting to order. On that note - you stand in the queue, remember to grab any cold drinks from the fridge if you want them then, then you order, get given your little tray with a bottle and a number, you walk into the dining area where a member of staff then seats you. The table turnover time is pretty spectacular, I thought we would never be able to get a seat (we did). Now back to the menu - if they'd display it better I don't think there'd be so much waiting because there's a menu at the till for you to peruse and decide on food.  There's a counter which has some incredible home-baked goods on display - sweet and savoury and the quiches looked fantastic.  We however decided to get the Haggis (plus neeps and tatties for 8.50), the beef lasagne (7.50) both a cold drink (Irn Bru and a diet coke) as well as two brownies.   We sat down, and chatted. Now, go to the bathrooms. I'm not kidding. I could have spent a good hour in here reading all the comments and quotes that HP fans scrawled over, well, everything. It makes my heart glow. All I wanted to do after washing my hands was head home to reread the series. But that's just me.   The food arrived, and you know, it was fine. It wasn't the best lasagne I've ever had, it wasn't the best haggis I've ever tried. The bread that came with the lasagne was a little out of place and the salad was a little lackluster.  The brownie on the other hand - hollaaaa, it was AMAZING. It was perfection. Sweet, chocolatey, dense but light and crispy and doughy and moist (ew what a horrible word).   If you don't mind being run down by tourists and probably overheating, and you do want a good brownie or some decent food, this is where you should come. Especially if you ever wanted to go to Hogwarts as well. One thing to note however, there is no wifi here. At all. "Pretend it's 1995 and talk to one another".

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

JO4ZYRUlIcOKVtTfj2bPTw.text: Must see if you're into Harry Potter, like I am. The coffee I had was good, as was the service when I was there. Make sure you take a trip to the toilet...it sounds weird, but you'll see.

j8znytVtsA4BEdCOIVhNqg.text: Had some great cake and coffee here, was not busy at all however we went around 8pm. Service and dessert was lovely, would come again!

Thenq888i_K65CqQ13ElNA.text: Since I am a huge Harry Potter fan, of course I had to go to this place, even if it was just to take a picture at the door.  I had read some reviews of the cafe saying that it wasn't as good as one might expect, so I avoided going there. But one day it was raining a lot and my friend and I wanted a cup of coffee, so we decided to give it a go.  We waited the queue by the counter (where you can buy badges, postcards with elephants and other elephant-inspired souvenirs), ordered our food and then headed inside to be directed to a table.  The waitress that took my order looked very upset, and it made me feel uncomfortable. I noticed none of the staff was smiling. I understand the place is very busy, but at least they could try to be a bit friendlier. Most people who go to the cafe are foreign people who maybe aren't sure of how to pronounce some words, and if the staff is impatient, it makes them feel insecure. I had a slice of Nutella cake and a mocha, and my friend had tea and a biscuit. I feel we paid too much for what it actually was. Sure, the cake was tasty and the coffee was good, but the portions were too small.   The coolest thing about the place is the bathroom. The walls are completely covered in writing from Harry Potter fans all over the world, thanking J.K. Rowling and quoting bits from the books and movies. I liked that a lot, but I was expecting some more Harry Potter/ Rowling inspired stuff.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Small mocha (£2.50) and cake (£3.95)
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

laETqQnaEc8Fwbm3kHMhAQ.text: Sadly this place will probably stay in business for the foreseeable future riding off its Harry Potter fame. We attempted to come here three different times, twice their card machine was out and they were only taking cash. Third time was supposed to be the charm.   It was incredibly disappointing. The food, service and decor were mediocre at best, and the castle was obscured by trees and poor positioning of tables. This place has so much potential and they aren't taking advantage of it. There are way to many tables and chairs, making the place feel crowded. I can't imagine a writer coming here to get much work done. You get the sense the place is all tourists and no locals.

DC7iZ3MShEARnEu2zeoyBQ.text: This large and famous cafe, known for the fact the J.K. Rowling wrote the first Harry Potter book here, is certainly worth checking out if you're in Edinburgh. The atmosphere is quite lovely. There's a small area up front with seating, but also a large and open space in the back with high ceilings, more seating including some sofas, and plenty of elephant decorations. The girl's bathroom is amazing since it is literally a shrine to Harry Potter, which every single surface (walls, mirrors, soap dispensers) covered in words and scribbles dedicated to HP. The boys' bathroom is not nearly as graffiti'ied...sorry lads. They've also got some interesting HP/J.K. Rowling articles and drawings on one wall.  The food at this cafe is mediocre. Fills you up, but nothing particularly flavorful. My vegetarian chili and my friend's steak pie was decent. My other friend mostly liked the pulled pork focaccia. The coffee and tea drinks were better though and worth trying.

Q8sgQhftNaRMABLVNocoSw.text: Most notably know for JK Rowling's spot where she began the Harry Potter series, this quainter little tea and some edibles.  The coffee is decent and the tea equally so.  Be prepared to see tons of fans snapping pictures outside and within.  This has became a tourist destination, even if it's closed.  If it weren't for the book series this red little edifice would be easily passed.  Perhaps before her fame that is exactly why she chose this place.  Worth a visit if you're a fan.  It's a decent experience if you're just dropping in for tea and something light to eat.

Bb8tb3Y2MD0e7QGgIxDUsg.text: Terrible place. I like to give it zero if it is available. We are visiting Scotland and my kids like to see where harry potter was written. I took them there. However, we had a terrible experience. We try to order food on the menu and was told that they were not available. We order substitute food but the dishes we got was not what we ordered. I told the waiter that the food is not what we ordered. He yelled at me and ask me to leave if I do not want it. I ask them who is the manager before I leave and was told the waiter who is serving us is the manager. This all happened in front of my kids.... Do not eat there and buy anything there. It will ruin your kids' whole day.

uqbhpQR1G__-UAKVqaUYqA.text: The coffee good but not great, the snack was okay but we came here not for the food, we came all the way from California, doing "HP tour" for me (I grew up reading HP and my kid who now also an die hard fans too), we ended our HP tour where it all began, here, yes , HERE!  We were lucky, we came during off season, so we able to get in and sit in the backroom with window overlooking the Edinburgh Castle.  JK Rowling often came here and sat in the backroom to save on the heating bill and rumor has it, she had Edinburgh Castle in mind when she wrote about Hogwarts. The view was so dreamy in a cloudy day, unbelievable and amazing view!  We bought some souvenir from here and took a lot of pictures, check the bathroom too if you here.  And the service was so so, they didn't even try to make a small talk, but again, we came here not for the service or the food.

rUK4iytUNKz_q9cTMVt-_g.text: Oh that touristy crowd!  Little did I know that this is where JK Rowling supposedly birthed HP.  In afterthought, I cringe at my naiveness to walk into that obvious tourist trap.  But at least... Good cappuccinos & lattes were enjoyed with prudent cake.  And... Lovely is the view, what with that castle and all.  Just these two aforementioned points warrant the 3 stars.  And maybe the fact I would reluctantly bring out of town-ers for the experience at being at one of those listed popular cafes..  But ohh that crowd.  ohh the line. OH me, oh my the hectic rush & clatter and "please wait to be seated" AFTER your order rule.  With heavy duty bus boys/servers/hostesses swooping in to and fro 360, tight elbow space on rickety chairs and being given the hawk eye to finish off and move along..  It should be renamed, Tourist Cafeteria.

yqMVQG75H9CUbizKpkKMWA.text: I visited here since it's called "the birth place of Harry Potter." Their espresso was great and the staff were very friendly. It's a great place to come with friends to relax in the afternoon and chat

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Espresso over ice

TzCchleZFD2mX1SS8yM8TA.text: The main attraction of elephant house is that JK Rowling wrote a good portion of Harry Potter at the cafe. It was enjoyable to sit in the back room where she had sat and see the view she had seen while writing the book. The cappuccino was delicious as was the Earl Grey tea. We also had a brownie and a salted caramel brownie - - both gluten-free and delicious. However, the service was not good. We had a wait time of over 10 minutes even though we could see several clean tables. The waitress, working in a tea shop, didn't know what Earl Grey was. An extra item also was added to our bill. They removed it fairly quickly, but it took forever to get the bill in the first place. They also messed up the order. Very cool bathroom with tons of Harry Potter graffiti Decour. Nice decor--love the elephants! Also - - they could not except credit cards at the time we went, so make sure you have cash!

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

PlwkoWljGJA6TXmyoHO0SA.text: The chocolate cake tasted like a stale Tastycake. Which isn't that bad, but it's not good either. We were seated fairly quickly, but the staff spent the rest of our visit gossiping in the front. We could have written a book in the amount of time we waited. The only magic here is how they managed to look so busy without actually doing anything. Three stars for Azcaban's cafeteria.

cVN4NIvhfoqhWUs1nf0g4w.text: Yes, the Elephant House is lovely, and yes, it has a good atmosphere, but listen up: do not attempt to go in on a rainy Wednesday afternoon after 5. It's so crowded it took 20 minutes just to get a seat! (My partner in coffee crime had suggested we meet there and I was loathe to hop back out into the rain again).  Having said that, nomnomnom, good coffee. There are several ways to get me happy and not burning the coffee or milk it comes with, is definitely one of them. I was pleasantly surprised as I really didn't expect anything too impressive coffee-wise, mainly because of the touristy nature of the place.   Boy was I wrong. It's lovely, and cozy, and good for conversations that last for hours, and, yes, on a rainy afternoon I fully understand why half of Edinburgh wants to hide within these four walls. It's just too popular for it's own good, that's all.

ycb42CzuJwow7sEmKINB0g.text: Nice and cosy cafe. We had just coffee and tea but it was good. Nice pictures on top of coffee :) For elephant lovers! Do not forget to visit bathrooms!!

3ZBnWp51UgGH_0d4Y8hyzQ.text: There was no line when we went for lunch today, so we had a very good experience; the place was not crowded either. I ordered the Soup of the Day along with a Mocha, and both we delicious! The ambience is calm and relaxing. Also, the bathroom is also has some interesting Harry Potter 'art.'

k_CucXiqLNkOrzX1BROx1w.text: Bad service, ok food. When I ordered my drink the waiter said "do you even know what's in that?" And looked at me, disgusted...I guess he doesn't like cafe au laits. Our barista was a skinny white guy with an attempted Mohawk and glasses, after insulting not only mine but my sisters drink choice, he never have us a number, and this never brought us our food. My sister had to actually go to the kitchen talk to them and finally bring the food herself, when we asked the waiter where the food had been he sneered "oh, looks like I forgot" I also saw the other barista be really rude the the woman in line behind us. After all the rudeness, the food wasn't even good, my sisters scone tasted like it was from a tesco bakery, and, after the service we had here, it probably was.

bv_pQ92SGdXPdiw05jw9nA.text: Last week I decided to drive up to Edinburgh for a mini holiday and thought to check this place out. I actually did not know about this cafe and it's history until I discovered it through an Instagram profile. I was searching hashtags of cappuccinos and a delicious looking one popped up and the title said "Birthplace of Harry Potter" which drew me in right away because I am a big fan of the book series. I walked from my hotel to the Cafe and right when I saw it, I knew I would enjoy the view because it was located on George IV bridge which overlooked a good portion of the city including Edinburgh Castle! The front of the Cafe is painted in this nice blood red color and there is a poster of JK Rowling in the window which draws you. It looks very small when you first enter and you worry if they are going to have room for you as there are only a few stools/chairs for window seating. However, as you get close to the counter you realize that there is a much larger seating area in the back of the cafe. The Elephant House differs from a lot of cafe's in that you have to wait in line to be served at the counter and then wait to be seated, rather than taking your seat and ordering from there.  The menu was full of cute British and Scottish foods/pastries and a set of coffee drinks as well. I opted for the special of the day which was a lovely fresh mint tea and a slice of the homemade organic carrot cake. After paying things got a little tricky because the place was PACKED! The front of the cafe is first come first sit type of seating but the back room where JK Rowling sat and wrote the first few Harry Potter novels is assigned seating by a hostess. It seemed really crazy because we had no where to place our tray and had to stand holding it in that hectic crowded area while waiting to be seated. After 2 minutes we were seated with another group, which made me a bit awkward but quickly that faded because I wanted to relish in the ambiance of the room, the HARRY POTTER WRITING ROOM as I called it :). It was a nice back room, not a lot tables so many people shared with other customers they did not know. A lot of writers sitting on laptops or writing on pieces of paper for inspiration which I thought was really cute. The best part was the view from the back windows. Perfect panoramic view of the city and Edinburgh Castle. Was it a coincidence that Hogwarts looks EXACTLY like Edinburgh Castle? I think not! The mint tea was lovely and fresh and the cake was sweet but not too sweet and had amazing frosting. I decided to take a quick break to the bathroom where I was extremely surprised by the white walls covered in writing with notes from fans all over the world thanking JK Rowling and complimenting the books. I really enjoyed the whole experience except for seating situation and being forced to share a table with others who didn't seem too keen to be sitting with us either, but that quickly vanished after a few minutes. Great experience, good food and environment.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Front of the cafe
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Bathroom cover in thank you notes!
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. View

PyNmreyy-zXdbZ5Pfvf5Vg.text: Whenever I have visitors from out of town they insist we come here, and I'm always pleasantly surprised by how good the food is. Despite the fact that the actual food/drink is sometimes dwarfed by the Harry Potter connection, the cakes and full meals I've had here always go beyond the standard cafe fare. Interesting cakes (lavender, anyone?) and more always make for a pleasant stop along the typical walking tour of the area.

en_q-rB7ElrD3ig4Sgk3tg.text: So you are in Edinburgh and you want somewhere to have a nice breakfast....why not try The Elephant House....  In short: 1) great food (kinda important); 2) nice decor - there are elephants EVERYWHERE; 3) nice atmosphere - a mix of both locals and tourists; and 4) great history (someone penned the small art-house book series about a boy wizard here).  The price is right too and the food was good...I mentioned the food right?  Whilst the staff were nice I felt that they were understaffed and that this kinda spoilt things a little. This should not be taken to mean that the staff there were not doing their job properlly - this place was busy and the staff were like Scottish versions of Road Runner....keep up the good work guys....Beep Beep.  Okay that wasn't really a short review but I can be long winded.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

QctbLe1Z0k6riNF7apVv0A.text: Once upon a time, Ian Rankin, JK Rowling and Alexander McCall Smith used to go to The Elephant House to sit and write over endless cups of coffee. Lord knows what any of them would think if they went back for an espresso or latte now.   Aside from the terrible service and permanently stressed looking staff, the place is so darn busy it's difficult to get a table. Spring to summer especially, the cafe is jam-packed with tourists desperate to secure a seat with views of the Castle. To make it worse, there's merchandise everywhere you look, the music is insipid and there's a live webcam opening til closing time so strangers across the world can watch as you eat your lunch!   The biggest disappointment however, has to be the food and drink. On paper, soup, panninis, pitta, quiche and baked potatoes sounds quite promising but I suspect from tasting the last two that everything is part cooked in advance then microwaved. The coffee I ordered was equally bland and frothy.   Free Wi-Fi or not, The Elephant House are going to have to raise their game if they want to inspire a new generation of writers!

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

Jjt01ht_5BfaOZKVkcV3sw.text: The way some people talk about The Elephant House you would think it was going to lead us to the promised land. I have never really understood the delirium. For a start I'm not going to mention the "HP" word (clue: I'm not talking about the sauce).  The Elephant House does have some appeal. Yes its central location and large space are appealing, but that's somewhat negated if you can never find a seat and it takes half a day to ques. Yes its late opening hours are a great idea in a city where the only place you can go after 8pm is the pub or bed, but whats the appeal if your only option is overpriced coffee (which you probably still have to que for). Yes it seemingly has a good range of lunchtime snacks, but that's not much good if the portions are so small you question the fact you just ordered a meal, and so overpriced you need to get a second job to make up for it.  Maybe I've just been unlucky, maybe it's because of all the hype it was easy to feel let down. But i have always found The Elephant House to be offer pricey small portions of average food. It's fine if you can avoid the crowds but otherwise there are plenty of alternatives nearby.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

Kge1Vr4zI8VvIOGrAFy8iw.text: Since I reach Edinburgh for few months, I seldom having my meals outside. But I went for Elephant house for 2 times. I will go another 3, 4 or 5 times if I going out for dinner/ lunch.   The reason make me be a return customer is their food. I order Nanchos, pizza, homemade beef burger, salad. I would highly recommend Nanchos and salads. But 1 thing I don't like is their services. Maybe that time is peak hour and they are not able to provide good services.  Overall, you can go for this restaurant.Experience yourself.

6JTm9QYefYet8otPzk3uIQ.text: I realised, after my last review, that I've still never reviewed the Elephant House. I'm not sure how as I bring most people here when they're visiting me.  "Do you really?" I can hear you thinking. "But you've given it three stars!" Well, yes. As a cafe, it's not so hot. It's kind of expensive, although it's a lovely space. The service is as quick as it can be, given that it's almost always heaving in here with tourists wondering which table J K Rowling used to sit at. The cakes are fine. The hot chocolate is fine. It's just a nice place.  It's funny, but when you're inside you wouldn't necessarily know this was "the place". The theme is, fittingly, elephants. There are elephants everywhere. It's quite sweet. People don't come for the elephants, though. They come for the magic.  The Elephant House, you see, touts itself as The Birthplace Of Harry Potter. Everyone knows the tale - that Jo Rowling, a penniless single mother, used to spend hours in an Edinburgh cafe, writing the book about a boy wizard that would, once published, lift her almost overnight to international literary superstardom. Well, the Elephant House, like many other establishments in Edinburgh, claims to be that cafe. Unlike many other establishments, however, here people have bought into the story. The tourists are fully invested in it. You can see how, gazing out of the large window at the back directly onto the majestic crags of the castle, someone might conceive the notion of Hogwarts. On the website, there's even an interview with the writer from shortly before the publication of the second book, filmed at the cafe (which incidentally is worth a watch because it's endearing how thrilled she is with sales that now pale in comparison to current figures).   Now, I don't want to get into a discussion on the nature of truth; this is a cafe review. BUT - whether or not it's True that she actually wrote there is, I think, not important. What's important is that everyone believes it. It's got a kind of truth of its own. Which leads me on to why I bring everyone here for a quick cup of tea, despite the big crowds, the big prices, the fact that while the food is pleasant there are many other places doing much nicer stuff nearby...  The toilets. You have to go into the toilets.  Obviously, I don't know what the men's loo is like, but if it's like the ladies', then it's a strangely uplifting experience. The walls are covered in graffiti: scribbled letters of gratitude, love and affection to the writer who changed the world and to the characters who are so real to so many. There are silly references, in-jokes about in-jokes, sketchy doodles and deeply heartfelt missives of appreciation, and never has finding words of love written on the wall of a public toilet been so innocent and so beautiful. Hogwarts might be fictional, but the magic here is real.

5Q7erXtJAKafemIu7ZM7CQ.text: I did not know that it was where J K Rowling wrote Harry Potter when I found the place... That changed after a trip to its toilet and a quick Google search.  It's often packed, the food is good and the staff are friendly.  I've had my fair share of its marvelous cakes, coffee and if you're looking for a real meal... I've enjoyed its chicken salad, and its pizza is pretty decent. The nachos are always a must for my friends and I. The price is slightly above average for a poor scholar but it's worth it as the portions are big enough to share.  I can see why it's a lovely place to write in... Not a bad place to hang out, I can totally imagine myself kicking back here... writing...  New in Edinburgh? Go for it!

v1hmvjMnz4SdSZa9io9sQw.text: Nice place to spend an afternoon and read. The gimmicky t-shirts and posters on the wall aren't my favorite thing, but the staff don't mind if you hang around for a while. No wifi is a bit of a downside, but the coffee is good and the food's nice too. Plus, it's fun to see all the notes to JK Rowling in the bathroom.

4Xj0jumclXghAel0nexSvg.text: I waited more than 15 minutes in the door, and I asked an employee when we will be attended. He disappeared and never responded. Nobody cared about the people that were waiting, so we finally left and had a wonderful dinner across the street.

-oUONqTTs3GZR_NPme7jLg.text: Wizards aside, there are other reasons to visit The Elephant House.  I do believe that many people visit it because of the quality of what is offered, rather than purely because someone (supposedly) wrote some books there.  I've been here a few times now, and have enjoyed each one.  It does tend to be busy, especially in the summer with all the tourists, but come in the winter during term time, and it's the perfect hideaway for that last minute essay-writing session.  I think that coming into this place without knowledge of the wizard-based hype is the best thing to do.  The food is fairly standard cafe-bistro style, and has always satisfied me in quenching hunger.  This place enjoys a great view of the castle from an assortment of different tables in the back area, with a few tables near the main servery at the front.  I'm pleased that The Elephant House has stuck to its roots, with lots of elephant-based things.  I wouldn't have wanted it to turn into some big Harry Potter shrine, as that would ruin what is a lovely little cafe.  I hope that they keep it this way.  I think if it changed, I would stop going.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

4Y6hWUufjrDq7zxWmy5i-g.text: I was a bit worried that a horde of Harry Potter fans would seek me out and cause me harm if I wrote a poor review for this place, but judging by the other comments I'm certainly not alone in my misgivings.   Chaos when ordering, weak coffee and a lack lustre menu, together with an overall sense of rush to get out left me feeling more than a little let down. I remember coming here years ago to see a mate play in a band and was quite taken with the setup.  Less so now.    It's little wonder Rowling sought escape in fantasy fiction if reality can be this depressing.

iCzdaS52jps1fZ6g_0k_5w.text: Having avoided this place at first, due to the threat of tourists and a milion Harry Potter fans, I found myself meeting friends here on a Thursday after work. I was sceptical at first as the ordering point was chaotic and it took awhile to get an order taken but once I was served I was impressed. A tapas style board arrived with olives, tortilla and mediterrean veggies - yum and all gluten free (if the bread is not added to it). A great range of cakes is available and I was impressed there were around 5 choices of proper gluten free cake (Victoria sponge, almond cake, chocolate cakes), and not just the usual chocolate brownies.  For locals wanting to try it, I suspect a non busy time such as late afternoon mid-week would mitigate some of the issues mentioned in previous reviews but I have already recommended The Elephant House to other friends.

R817yMQgGO6hUHt5t4mt1Q.text: Yes, so this is where J K Rowling supposedly sat to write a tiny bit of one of the Harry Potter novels. And yes, from one of the windows you can see the castle. But let's face it, you can see the castle from most parts of the city centre, and to be honest your chances of getting anywhere near that particular table are slim to none anyway.  Aside from the gimmicks, it's just another coffee place that serves soups/sandwiches/cakes etc. Except it's not even a particularly good one. The way you carry your tray away from the till down the long, narrow room to try and find the last available table whilst getting stared at by all the other smug-looking people already sat down, will make you feel like you're back at school again. Except at school, you didn't pay around 8 for an ok-ish sandwich and a cup of tea.  If you judge a place based on how busy it is, then there aren't enough stars in the world to award this place. But unfortunately it's not just can't-find-table-anywhere busy, it's also the staff who are rushing round like lunatics and they certainly don't move out of the way for you... even with your huge school dinner tray.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

qaAV2K2WRUloJ3uw5xM9vw.text: This is the supposed home and birth place of JK Rowlings Harry Potter, and because of this it has become a massive tourist trap, for those who seem to think that JK might be there penning her next creation. And yes, the Elephant House is an insperational place to write - if you manage to get in here away from the tourists, you will find a nicely decorated cafe with beautiful views, a friendly atmosphere and nice staff. Get it on a bad day, and you will enter a place that is too crowded, hot, slow and a bit nightmarish if im frank.  The food here really seems to have gone down hill as well, in my first year Elephant House being so close to the uni was my breakfast port of call - but now the food seems over priced, and generally a bit crap - i really didnt enjoy my paninni and coffee.  The Elephant House seems to have given itself to the tourists, and really gone down hill.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

-oVG1JSWM1AdoxY_TVQAsA.text: Stop by to see one of many birthplaces of Harry Potter, don't waste your money here! Don't order more than a drink or a cake! Not worth it! Really bad service! Not one came to take our order and they charged for service fee! How ridiculous! Will never come here again!!!!!!

RnFUUuO0mDpbr8RYUbAsuQ.text: Very friendly and accommodating staff (considering they likely get HP mega fans pouring in constantly). I ordered a double espresso and chocolate croissant with my fiance, and we just sat and took in the view of the Edinburgh Castle in the distance. Also don't forget to write your name on the bathroom walls to join the Dumbledore Army (I guess that's a must?)

VHlgBvkiJOzv2aYiB-7kEw.text: Food is ok.  Service is just ok.  I bet that most of guests are tourist not locals.  However, it is worthy to come and take pictures, or wait for half an hour to eat in, if you are the fans of Harry Potter or JK Rowling.  Full of graffiti in the toilets.

5Q3oL7iKfnTLE2rOyHc1DA.text: A nice place to eat, not too much jk Rowling going on. Our son enjoyed it, the food was tasty and correct portion size

QuvK0mwRRyl3Wk9ewY0KKw.text: I guess this place attracts tourists because of the connection with Harry Potter, other than that I don't think this place deserves any recognition. The service is extremely slow, the staff is rude and just shrugs away from you and the food is bad. The coffee is cold, cakes are meh! We ordered two coffees and a hot chocolate, all were at a temperature little more than room temperature. The chicken katzu rolls had chicken undercooked and the bread overcooked, the salad had rotten leaves and tomatoes. I appreciate however that they refunded us our money for the food.

OCsZxS1RNQ1RAdAchY38Yw.text: My 11-year old is a Harry Potter fan, so this needed to part of our itinery.  We stopped in on our first day in Edinburgh.  I was expecting to it to be really busy, but it wasn't too bad.  We weren't able to get one of the coveted tables to looked out to the castle, but we still enjoyed our visit.  The bathrooms were the AWESOME!

mIVWZBT-PNNfpx2ukB27bw.text: When my wife and I walked in, we we're relatively excited to experience the "gourmet" tea they boast about on their site. And then...  1. We waited several minutes before someone even acknowledged that we were waiting to be seated. Five staff members... FIVE... walked consistently passed us without any acknowledgment at all. 2. We were finally sat only to wait another 10 mins without any waiter coming to our table. Then we finally thought that perhaps we were meant to order at the front. We approached the cashier to order, who told us that a waiter will take our order, so we sat back down, waited another 10 mins until we finally hounded down a waiter and asked to please order. 3. Turns out the tea is not so gourmet. The filters that came with the tea were filthy and hadn't been washed (see photo). There were no sweetener options (which is surprising for gourmet) other than a wide-mouth container on the table that you have to dive your spoon into and  given the cleanliness of their filters, I can only imagine how unhygienic the sugar bowls are.  Overall, this place was a great disappointment and clearly relies on their connection to a famous author to stay in business.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

ymNURP_hMssk8V4-PusoAg.text: I only had coffee here so I can't speak to the restaurant experience. It certainly draws a tourist crowd due to its association with Rowling and Potter. I thought the coffee was very tasty as was the dessert I had. The service was a bit hasty but the place was packed so what can you expect. It was quaint and iconic. Neat little place. They were out of coffee mugs which was a disappointment.

TCDHh0ZICoJN-g_tJt2x0w.text: I visited here because I'm a Potter fan.  Very busy place, nice staff; however, Edinburgh was having a "heat wave" and with no AC, well, it was a little warm in the restaurant.  It took about 15 minutes for someone to take our order which we understood.  They were packed and we weren't in a rush.    We decided to try haggis for our first time at this place and so glad we did!  It was good paired with the mashed potatoes and turnips.  We got the chicken pot pie as well with a coffee (even though it was scorching in there!)  They have a few souvenirs you can buy which is fun and nice.  I did buy a medium ladies shirt and it runs small.  Just please be careful if you buy a t-shirt - they are smaller than what we are use to in the states.  Unfortunately, I washed it and dried it on medium heat before I wore it and shrunk it more, so it may be my 10 year old nieces present from Scotland now.  Great place to visit if you get the chance!

vQDfqwm1HMSxdlGF9BKnyA.text: avoid this! Food quality is really poor! Save your money! Cannot believe such a restaurant with this poor quality is still running

Yg-icpPKIZ2o9HSKti03bg.text: I am a Harry Potter fan and when we were planning on visiting Edinburgh, i knew we had to include a stop at The Elephant House. also known as the birthplace of Harry Potter. It's a cozy cafe and I would have walked right by it if it wasn't for the tourists taking pictures at the front. I ordered a cup of tea (turns out I ordered a small pot) so I could sit and take in the cafe. It's filled with elephant artwork (hence the name) and plenty of places to sit. There are great views of Edinburgh castle if you sit near the window.   My tea was good and staff was friendly. Just mind the crowds.

c23WN6VB795-vC7opLMERA.text: Noteworthy for being the haunt of JK Rowling. It's said that she took the name off a gravestone in the cemetery in the back for one of her characters.  The coffee is OK.  Always busy because of it's connection to Harry Potter.

WbLQcKj-ErS9wMDN7edkag.text: Yes, I know this cafe is covered in Harry Potter-ness, but I swear, that's not why we went in. I mean, I'd be lying if I said I didn't want to geek out a bit on whatever Rowling-inspired nonsense they had inside, but what made us step inside were the drinks and the sweets.  We're kind of simple like that.  The first thing I noticed about the cafe was that it was packed. The second was that it was bloody hot in there!  They had two girls working the register and making drinks, but for some reason, the line stalled. Once we got to the front, we placed our orders (chai tea and a brownie for me, large latte and an apricot granola bar for him) and waited while they prepared the drinks.  After paying, we turned towards the dining room and waited to be directed to a table (which I'm guessing they do to stem the tide of people). We were given a booth at the front of the restaurant, which, despite the number of pillows on the bench, was kind of unwelcoming. I think a number of bottoms over the years have smooshed the softness out of the pillows.  Still, it was nice to relax a bit, especially after having just run 10 miles during the Great Edinburgh Run. The drinks were very good, and the sweets hit the spot.  There wasn't nearly as much Rowling-inspired nonsense inside as I thought there'd be, but I did manage to find a collage of pictures and such. And apparently the bathroom walls are covered with notes to the author, should she ever go back. I can't speak to that personally, because I did not go in, but I glimpsed the walls when the door opened, and they definitely were covered in writing. I get my information from the Harry Potter Trail guide.  This is a nice place to while away a few hours in the afternoon, over a nice warm cup and a tasty little treat. Prices seemed to be fair, as well.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Latte, chai tea, brownie and apricot granola bar

vOIFJU_gSktXKhZnq5ekHQ.text: If you are a fan of Harry Potter I would say this place gonna be a dream for you. But as a normal people who just want to look for some good cake and coffee in Edinburgh I am not sure it would be a good choice for you. This place is always packed with too many tourists around the world and they only have 2 toilets for each gender so you could imagine that it would be a queue to go toilet in a peak hour here - and note that somebody could stay a bit long in toilet to take photo of all things that Harry Potter fan draw in there!

YzZdfR9SmXpUt1qNjD4lyw.text: I really enjoyed coming to this place, especially as a Harry Potter fan.i already knew I was going to stop by because I wanted to see how jk Rowling must have felt writing her book I this cafe. It did not disappoint. I love the elephant theme and appreciated the little Harry Potter knock knacks it kept all around. I saw the first edition signed by Rowling herself! I bought a few cute postcards too. I wasn't expecting much in terms of the pastries but was pleasantly surprised they were actually really good. Only downside was how small and busy it is

vNC8pJZWAv7wMizQ0mf7TQ.text: The thing I loved about this place is how much they have embraced being the birth place of Harry Potter- that made it quite enjoyable, as did all the elephant decorations and the kind staff. The two stars were more for the food and drink experience. The place was busy, but not that busy that it should have taken 30 minutes for our small coffees to arrive (after we had already waited 10ish minutes for someone to come grab our order), which came after our food. I ordered soup of the day, which ran out, so I decided to get the replacement soup, it happens. My husband ordered the goat cheese pizza which he did enjoy. We sat at the bar so we did have a view of the kitchen, and watched someone pick up our food to bring it over, and then put it back down a few minutes, not sure why. Maybe she realized we didn't have our coffees yet? If we hadn't felt like we had invested so much time waiting we probably would have left.

yMcJ-1_Gbm-KsLLVjtaJdQ.text: If you're a Harry Potter fan, it's a nice stop. The castle view is beautiful. We had coffee, a pot of tea, cookies and scones. Nothing to brag about, but good. The line was out the door. We were seated quickly since we were only getting coffee. The wait is longer for food.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

cQtNlLzX4q82oEByJLGxHw.text: The reason why I wanted to check out this place due to its Harry Potter history.  The service was very poor and the food was just mediocre.  I would suggest just to pop in for a pot of tea to check out the place but do not eat there.

gnTeo-caNRDhh_MqALeXTQ.text: So touristy!! Not worth a meal. The staff is rude and it's quite expensive for sub par food.

Z9Gkr4H-axWpi3SDAgmMtA.text: Location:  First off- if your Harry Potter fan, this is a must. You would be glad to know that this place is pretty easy to spot, and very close to the graveyard where J. K. Rowling was inspired to name some of her characters in her novels. If you want to stay here and eat, just get a pastry and a coffee or tea. You will want to wait for the big room in the back. You don't want to sit in the front room while everyone in line stares at you eating.  Please beware - not every table has a view of Edinburgh castle! When you are waiting in line (because you will be waiting in line if you want to sit) that first table you see straight ahead is one of the best tables to get a view. The second best view would be the middle table in the middle of the room. You would think being that this is such a popular - let's just say famous - place, their bathrooms would be cleaner. Don't get me wrong, stepping into the bathroom  is a nice read on the walls, but not the cleanest.   Food: The food is HORRIBLE! I ordered their basic Marguerite pizza and I swear it was out of a frozen box. I felt like I was eating cardboard. Again you are not here for the food, you're here because of Harry Potter. Am I right?? I do have to admit though, the bruschetta was AMAZING!!! But the smart thing to do here is to know that the food is not good, but try out a pastry and a coffee or tea. You won't be disappointed.  Customer service- The waiters and waitresses took a long time to take our order but it was packed at the time we came. Then again this place is always packed. They were very nice and kind but don't expect to eat right away. Take in the views and enjoy where JK started it all.   Overall- Like I said, if you are a HP fan this is a definite must. BUT DON'T COME HUNGRY!! Enjoy!

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. The room in the back.
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Inside the bathroom. Don&#39;t forget your sharpie to add to it!
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. View from the first table you see waiting in line.

8VshqFe_nhKcodTdmARLDQ.text: the quiche was super tasty and my boyfriend was in love with his vat of carrot and coriander soup. busy, not great seating and a bit cramped. but a nice little place.  they could stand to heat it a bit more, though.

cQyES6ZHTcq__zFuBh4Eiw.text: I'd agree with the general consensus here! Loads of hype but disappointing. Queues are always huge and because you get told off by staff for bagging a seat before you order, you can end up with a tray of food and then find there's nowhere to sit! More than once I've had to share a teeny table with strangers which was rather embarrassing. It's also rather on the expensive side for what you get, presumably because of all the unwitting tourists who come through the door after a bit of the Harry Potter experience! Nice tea in big teapots and great cakes, but the seating/queuing system and the pricey menu has put me off :(

GfjgcXbN2YGrCYpAfbK7tg.text: I've never quite figured out what it is with Edinburgh and elephants, but the Elephant House is the one place of many similar-named eateries that's worth a look-in if you like them - elephants that is. More so, if you like cakes, because there's a mighty fine selection. This is a busy place, and the place JK Rowling would go for coffee whilst penning the first part of her Potter adventures, apparently. Since then, Rowling has done wonders for the publishing industry and given a voice to all closeted young wizards. She's also enhanced the Elephant House takings, not least from tourists and festival-goers and avid Potter readers. A noticeboard brimful of scribbled messages plus cheap internet is a mine of information, especially if you're in town flat-hunting. Service is friendly enough, though sometimes a bit buffeted by chaos behind the counter. Coffee's not the best in town, but the Elephant House is definitely worth a visit.

nqZh7xc7yf9ucROOGhYjnw.text: I was really disappointed the one and only time I visited this Elephant House. Despite having great lunches at the other branch in the Bristo Square area, the evening meal I had here was dreadful. THe chicken burger I ordered was rock solid and quite possible still frozen. I realise chicken burgers aren't what the Elephant House is all about but still, I would have expected my meal to be at least edible. Ther service wasn't particularly welcoming either and I'm loathe to go back. I see other reviewers have had a different experience so perhaps this was a one off, but it would take a lot for me to be persuaded otherwise!

NUG9hh8U0s1WMzkP4MjhgQ.text: What a disappointment! We had heard such great things but.... the food is pre-processed. The eggs were rubber, the bacon was soggy, haggis was mush and the tomatoes were raw! The guys in the kitchen don't wear hats or an apron. OK the place does good coffee but there are better and it has to said... cheaper! I don't like posting a bad review but this was just plain shabby!

nMJHxMb1fOoRUXZLW8MGrQ.text: Elephant house is a nice cafe with good stylish decor, full of elephant figures, paintings and posters. It is the place where JK Rowling were writing her notes for famous Harry Potter series. The prices are alright and the coffee is good. The food and service lets the place a bit down though. For such a busy place the service is rather slow and you might have to wait a bit to actually get your coffee. The food isn't very high quality but it is cafe not restaurant.

PlUAfSSR7RwW0ZxtQbAYfA.text: It's True, the views are amazing but not sure the claim that some of the Harry Potter books were written here is entirely True (wasn't that Nicholson's before it closed?) Anyway, if you want a hot chocolate with cream, marsh mellow and flake this is the place. Queues usually go out of the door and wouldn't tend to have lunch there as choice limited, but generally nice tea and cakes.

_-GYVT3E9TCV6cuCQw46eQ.text: Oh dear dear dear. This place USED to be nice. But I'm only giving it two stars rather than one for the views out. The food would disgrace a greasy spoon or burger bar. It may LOOK as if it's going to be nice, but don't be fooled.   I ordered a burger, which was thin, dry, nasty cheap meat, on the cheapest possible white roll with a couple of slivers of tomato. No chips, as I'd foolishly expected. And get this, no sauces or relishes available. The waiter brought me salad dressing as the only thing they had! On a burger??? My partner's veggie pie was somehow both soggy and hard, and quite tasteless, disgusting.   Oh, and their "birthplace if Harry Potter" claim either. JK may have gone their a few times, but her main haunt was on Nicoson Street. It's obvious they get plenty of customers so I guess they are just so cynical they don't feel they have to bother with providing decent food. But I for one am never going back.

uX9_gT64dEYo9m0kpr7VUQ.text: Decent cafe with a cool bit of history to go with it (mentioned in every other review here) Nice view of the castle. The Mocha was good and food was decent.

S3MJvtjR71WpeQuccajIag.text: A pretty average cafe when it comes to food and drink. Nothing to write home about. But the view of the castle from the window is great!

PM8yEdugEIRgACKBqoj2rw.text: The Elephant House is the ideal place to take a visitor to when you have done all the touristy things in town and are dying for a coffee to perk and warm you up. Its location is the best thing about it, with privileged views of edinburgh Castle out of the back windows and within walking distance of the Royal Mile, Princes Street, the City Centre attractions and transport links. It serves good if slightly overpriced food, has a relaxed but busy atmosphere and is perfect for a quick bite. It is the type of cafe that stands out from the crowd of sandwich outlets with its more individual decor and undeniable charm. Take your granny or auntie when they come to visit but make sure to make them pick up the bill, especially if you're on a student's budget!

7f9eHhfGvQo8-2uoqV2m4A.text: This is a really great cafe, unexpectedly big there is plenty of room for everyone. There is a variety of food and drinks on offer and the service is really great, even when it's busy. It is spacious but still quite cosy, great for catching up with friends or even having a coffee with a book to chill out. A good escape from the busy centre of town.

28qiqtBVJCL2tu7D1J7pvg.text: Calling all aspiring would-be writers, it would seem they add little droplets of inspiration and sprinkles of wordly magic to the cakes in this little caffeine haven considering the dedicated caliber of customers i.e. J.K.Rowling, Alexander McCall Smith. Smooth aromatic coffee, Internet access and a mouth watering selection of savory and sweet delights on offer. Good luck attempting to count each and every elephant motifhas to be done!

koUjOq1GbUrrVw--s8yhBQ.text: I know, this is actually not the birthplace of Harry Potterbut at least, that's the place where J.K.Rowling got the inspiration for the cemetery in the Harry Potter's novels, from looking at Greyfriars Graveyard!   You won't believe it but you are actually in a bridge, it's George IV Bridge, just look outside the window and you will realise how high up you are!!!   It's a caffe where you can sit down and eat some of the nicest cakes and pastries in townyou even get ones with the shapes of Elephants!!! This place is decorated with elephants all around, photos, little statues, even some chairs have been shaped in an elephant shape   At least 15 different sorts of coffees to choose from, specially recommended to try the one with marshmallows and whipped cream on topalthough you also have diet-friendly options served with skimmed milk.   Shouldn't be forgotten to mention, that the prices are a bit over-rated and that it is really hard to find a table sometimes, so don't count on having a place to sit in.   By the way, you can also get Internet conection in there (unfortunately, you have to pay for that)

A7k5_rKu5MnBZq3o8MuOOw.text: Went for a Scottish breakfast with my partner food was quite good, nice setting, good price and large Breakfast Yum!

Kab2y3p0Us_0ygk0akLeSA.text: I of course as many others was drawn to this place because of J K Rowling but also for a secondary reasonI LOVE elephants so for me that made it more special than normal cafes epsecially with the elephant chairs. The food and drinks were good quality and the service is good also there are amazing views of the castle which I just think are some of the best in the city and its great to sit with a cup of tea and just stare at the impressive views. The only problem I have is that sometimes it is difficult to get a seat and sometimes you literally have to pounce on a table as soon as it becomes available even if it isn't big enough or small enough for your party.

xN_cpHhguiZSBzRGKREdGA.text: Lovely coffee shop which has lots of history. The coffee is fantastic, the cooked breakfast rolls are outstanding and the cakes are to die for!  This place is busy, people gather to meet friends, some come for client meetings, people work on their laptops or write in their journals. There are lots of big wooden tables, where people sit around for hours and the atmosphere is relaxed and friendly.

pKwXwyYZhywa6VvRZeO3zg.text: One of the many birth places of Harry Potter, the Elephant House cafe can be found on George the IV Bridge. The Elephant House is often rather busy, but it is large and if you're happy to share a large table with some people you'll always get a seat. As well as the cafe they also have internet access at the Elephant House these days, useful for the tourist needing to contact home. The food is decent cafe fare and not too bad a price for the centre of Edinburgh, the decor is what gives Elephant House its name. There are elephants everywhere here, for this reason it's a pretty good place to take the kids. Out the back window you get a nice view of the castle and Greyfriars Kirkyard which makes this cafe one of the nicer places to rest in the centre of town.

DievvYD1-AKz4i0vR2EkIQ.text: The sandwiches are pretty good, but it does tend to be busy all the time and getting a seat isn't always easy. Obviously, if you're a J K Rowling fan it might be worth popping in - but to anyone else it's really just a normal cafe. The staff were reasonably friendly, but didn't seem to be that bothered about sorting out the queue of people out the door.

i5LozGxatWSIp63IXn_yUg.text: If you are after good coffee, nice food, a pleasant place to sit, and attentive staff, then stay well clear. This is a tourist trap trading on past glories and tenuous Harry Potter connections (Rowling also wrote at other Edinburgh cafes which have the sense to downplay the links). The coffee is poor, with badly textured milk and too much froth, while food is over-priced and forgettable. The seating and ambiance is awkward, overcrowded, and especially in the back room, filled with screaming kids and tour groups. On the other hand, if you simply want to stare at the seats that J.K. Rowling sat in many years ago, then this is your place. But remember, she would not be found dead here now.

HysHrmftcqjUqFLKjsQfTw.text: I used to pop in here during my student days to listen to bands on a Thursday night, having not been there for years I recommended going to my partner as I had it in my memory as a nice, laidback place with tasty treats... I don'tknowwhat has happened since but I was very disappointed. We went in at 8pm and there was a notice advising us to wait to be seated, so we did... we were the only ones waiting yet the staff decided they could not see us. After 10 mins of standing there and being blatantly ignored we left feelingembaressed. So I don'tknow if the coffee is good or the treats are still tasty but I do know that the staff are rude and useless. I mentioned it to a friend who said she had managed to get seated fine but that her meal was poor and the staff looked bored so maybe that was a good thing we missed out.  Maybe I'll leave it another 4 years.

Fu_7HrZiN5k4Nf0zkvUNiA.text: The famous cafe that housed J K Rowling in her pre-fame years of coffee room scribbling. The lovely cafe, which is charming in its own right, expectedly attracts all the fans of the authoress as well as a few amateur writers hoping that the place will bestow equal fame and success upon all it's clients. Other writers have claims upon the place, and cuttings on the wall display clippings from Ian Rankin books and other claims to fame. Fame, nonetheless, hasn't gone to anybody's head here, and the atmosphere remains laid back and comfortable, having admirably avoided becoming a Disney-esque attraction. The cakes are delicious and perfect for a late evening indulgence. The beautiful elephant chair is one to be grabbed, and the other paintings and elephant-themed pieces add all the gentle majesty that the beasts inspire, encouraging the writers in the corner to think big.

Wt-ISZn_nOqw8TZ4CE_3LA.text: A friend recommended this place to me as a coffee house with a character. So far her recommendations were on the spot. I went, I saw, I conquered. With the view of the castle and their specialty drinks, it was a great way to warm up on a chilly Edinburgh day (hot chocolate involving Baileys or Scotch works for me just fine). If only I had enough talent, I could write here the whole novel or, perhaps, short stories involving elephants? - Very writing friendly surrounding  Well - you just need occasionally phase out the tourists.   The other day I met a couple of them - they were studying their maps and guides very carefully, keeping their voices down. I wasn't sure - I thought I heard some German word here or there, but if they were Germans indeed, I would have heard them loud and clear. I guessed Swiss, whose frustration around the world is being mistaken for Germans or being hardly noticeable at all. I couldn't resist approaching them. It turned out they were Swiss from Zurich, a couple of days in Edinburgh on their way to Highlands. After a long chat, they had a few very useful suggestions for me, who still knows zilch about the city. Sometimes it pays off to come across some organized tourists  As opposed to the one writing these words - a disorganized, ignorant me .   One star down for lack of wireless. They have their own internet stations, if you need a quick check. Also, avoid the place if you do not like crowds - it has become too popular for its own good

5vElhDG-BehHy8DniolgYQ.text: A lot of cafes say that they are where JK Rowling wrote harry Potter. Maybe this is, maybe it isn't, but it's still the place I like to come for a bagel at lunchtime, a slice of cake and a cup of tea in the afternoon or brunch with friends at the weekend. The only thing which lets it down is the (extremely) slow service at the counter. I have been left standing there for ten minuted before being able to place an order whilst the staff make a cup of tea for another customer, but it has a great atmosphere and the food is lovely. It even has an alcohol license so you can have a beer with your cake if the fancy takes you!

pXCA3eL9tg6L06TefpImXQ.text: The Elephant house is nice, but the staff can be totally dreamy sometimes and a bit slow. Firendly though and food is nice - soooo busy sometimes

4iEypuZvsexkj748iZuyuA.text: Definitely a tourist trap. I got a hot chocolate, which tasted like swiss miss. The waitress asked if I wanted whipped cream without telling me that it was extra. It was 60p for a little bit of canned whipped cream that was completely melted into the hot chocolate! Such a rip off.

-k4w3bGncKQXkfleBKydnQ.text: Alright... save your money and don't order more than a drink or a bit of cake here.  Pros- Nice atmosphere Friendly service Good selection of beverages  Cons- Actual food not worth the price Bit of a wait for mediocre food Busy Potter-hype tourist trap  So, the drink I ordered (Fluer's delight?? Hot cocoa and Baileys basically) was good, as was the slice of Victoria sponge my partner and I shared. I wished we has stopped there, but we were a little hungry, so we ordered a bowl of olives and a salad.  Canned sliced black and green olives. For 5. Thought we ordered the tomato, basil, and onion salad, but there was a miscommunication and we got the chorizo salad instead. Bit of spring mix, a few tomatoes and cucumber slices, the canned olives I mentioned previously, and pepperoni like slices of chorizo. No dressing, just chorizo grease.  28 altogether, for two drinks, an appetizer, a sad salad and a piece of cake.    Take your Potter photos and maybe grab a hot drink, but don't bother with the food here.

NPJtR_0hrD6iZVnSeZveEQ.text: Worst service ever. The waiters and the manager are very rude, it's not worth to spend your Galleons there, even if you are a big potterhead. A picture outside will be enough, saving you some stress of rude people ruining a magical moment.

2UGonhWvVty_u8Aq4rDp9Q.text: Food was good but service was somewhat slow. We did have to wait for about 10 min to be seated. We came around 10:30 AM. Our waitress was very nice though. I had the ham and cheese with tomatoes croissant which was enjoyable. We also had a slice of carrot cake, which was dry.  We went here solely because this was where J.K. Rowling wrote some of Harry Potter. It was a nice experience but would not do it again.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

VkrkeFCFhF850RaljGvAow.text: Ohhhhh Elephant House. What, exactly, kept JK Rowling coming back here while she was writing the first installment of Harry Potter? It can't possibly have been the service because ,in my experience, it was sub par at best. Was it the food? If so then, prey tell, what did she order? Out of the four of us in my party no one got a meal worth returning for. The summer vegetable soup tasted as if it came from a factory not a kitchen. The chicken pie was mainly crust with almost  no chicken. The mash and gravy were bland. The fish pie was ok but had tiny shreds of fish instead of nice big chunks. And lastly the jacket potato that I ordered with chili con carne was so burnt that hardly any of it was edible. How do you mess up a jacket potato?! I didn't mind having to fetch my own water but it would have been nice to have had the communal pitchers replenished more often than they were.   Oh well, it is The Royal Mile, so one expects to get ripped off. I'll just chalk it up to be a tourist and move on.

IZeDMrs4XR-wMwzKFOlpvA.text: Ok Harry Potter fans.... this is a major at stop for you in Edinburgh.   BUT. The tea and desserts are very good.  So non Potter fans this is a a great pace for a snack and tea.  It seems crowded but the staff is fast.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

XrqzU8TrLk6utsuhK26pbA.text: First impression, this is so cool know JK Rowling wrote most of the Harry Potter books here but as we started to order we were told at least four things on the menu they didn't have anymore of. But the food we got was great! The Mallow Chocolate was so freaking good!

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

ch4z5zXwnaETF0rBVljnLw.text: They are lucky JK Rolling used to write there. As a food joint, I have not had worst in a while.  This place is a proper scam.  1) I got a breakfast from them, and they used powdered eggs! Unbelievable! And I had to pay for it? Seriously? I cannot believe I paid for fake eggs! Tomato also badly cooked. And bacon is old. 2) coffee was horrible, lacked coffee and way too much milk 3) unfriendly staff - force us to order first while we are carrying lots of luggage 4) too Asian - im Asian myself and I found them way too much. Chinese everywhere, basically a tourist scam targeting Chinese 5) the walking tour guide told us they actually paid royalty to put "home of Harry Potter" there, in fact the real home was a cafe "Spoon" which used to be owned by JK Rolling'a brother in law  Tip - go have a look at their bathroom, lots of messages there  Note: they do charge you to just go in have a look

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Yes it&#39;s a decent view

SrE9jEQqu9wr6adnJaYlig.text: Got the vegetarian chili, it was very delicious but it had the European portion size LOL. Let's just say it was adjustment from  the American portion size of food.  The server was very nice, the place wasn't very full at the beginning of the meal, but at the end it was pretty packed. Got some traditional Scottish desserts and apple pie. Would I eat there again? You betcha. The Harry Potter connection was pretty cool too.
