6taBdt-dlq8_GGPqJSFIDg.text: It's a nice coffee shop and wasn't too busy when we went, especially for being a stop for Harry Potter fans. We just ordered cappuccinos and shortbread but enjoyed both.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

cQgkUyU9X58BnJP7U3r-3A.text: I'm not sure if we received the foreigner/tourist service, or if the service at The Elephant House is that poor. Family of five, stopping to grab a quick bite to eat: ordered five hot drinks (two spiked), one cheese pizza, and an order of nachos.  We were given nothing in the form of cutlery. I had to use my coffee spoon to cut the pizza, as the wait staff never checked on us again. We flagged one waiter down for napkins, he brought us a stack of napkins on top of our bill.   Drinks were okay, pizza was okay, nachos were better.  If you are a potter fan, pay the suggested  donation to take photos. Hungry and thirsty family, there are different establishments in the area to spend that hard earned .  We do not recommend That Elephant House.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

j4umccky95gnt9-bVnp7Ag.text: I visited Edinburgh with my friends for a weekend, so we felt like we had to experience all of the tourist stops, which included this cafe since we're Harry Potter fans. It was great to have a lovely view of the city from our table, and we appreciated the quick service, but I wasn't impressed with our meal at all. We ordered the Scottish Pancakes, which were flimsy and plain. The portion size was also very small. The latte I ordered was fine, but I would have been perfectly happy going to Costa instead.   Overall, I'd recommend maybe just coming here for coffee or tea early in the morning -- that way you won't have to wait in a long line (after 9:00 there were people lined up waiting for a table), you'll get to see the cool writing on the bathroom walls, have a nice view of Edinburgh, and leave whenever you'd like. I wouldn't say it's the place to come for a good meal.

XSNlKOTcH_3jAwHRBRLLsg.text: Agree with most of the reviews here that the food is pretty average, but if you are a Harry Potter fan then what you are really coming here for is to visit the bathrooms, which have been turned into a graffiti shrine to all things Potter. Bring a Sharpie along to add to the collage. The views over the castle are nice too if you can get a table up the back near the windows.

7OzySU8BpiC24YgtkrqcmA.text: Seems to be a mixed bag of reviews on here...  Here what I was expecting.  Busy, overpriced, terrible.  Honestly, it wasn't any of those things.  For my family showing up in the middle of Edinburgh summer, the place was pretty quiet.  Service was OK (no worse than the rest of the UK), food was very reasonably priced and decent (liked the lasagna) and I loved the quirkiness of the place.  I feel this place could take their very well known fame and jack up the prices, redo the place and still capitalize on their fame.  None of this was done, so I believe it is still worth the visit.  It's even a good place to just check out in general in the middle of touristy Edinburgh.

nALbL21RTfDR7_kN183bxg.text: This is a fun place to have a coffee or hot chocolate while in Edinburgh.  I got the hot coconut milk which I liked.  My friend liked the affogato and my other friends enjoyed their spiked hot chocolates.  I got to try tiffin which is a Scottish dessert that reminds me of fruit cake.   We got to see the spot where it is said JK Rowling wrote Harry Potter.  Through the window you can see Edinburgh Castle.   The bathroom is kinda fun with sharpied notes fans have written to JK Rowling.  One said "I get sleezy for Ron Weesley" haha.    This places has good dessert drinks and is cool for Harry Potter fans.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. View from the spot JK Rowling sat at.
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Affogato, spiked hot chocolates, and hot milk and some desserts.  I tried tiffin for the first time.

wKLnYtIoGjCrNKAH69ZhmA.text: The perfect little pastry and breakfast/coffee spot. Plus if you're a Harry Potter fan you'll be in Harry Potter fan you'll be happy to see the sights and the graveyard in the back. Be sure to step in the toilet and take a look around at the "writing" on the walls

-rLHdv6BzniH10go6RgnBw.text: A cute setting with great food! It's a busy restaurant and is not great for large groups. I tried everyone's desserts and everything was delicious. The chicken pot pie was great comfort food.

photos.caption: Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Purple velvet cake was to die for
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Yummy chicken pie with mash

V1i88R-Ov25DlcdDkF1E-w.text: It's a good thing Harry Potter was born here, for them. Otherwise, this would have failed years ago. The service is atrocious and the food is simply passable. Want to see where JK worked? Great. Otherwise, move along.

vvK20s0x5PNej01cSrU8Og.text: Full disclosure: this review is 5 stars because of the extremely emotional reaction I had as it relates to Harry Potter, and hey, I liked my spiked coffee, too.  So we'd just passed through Victoria Street, and I was already primed for more Harry Potter. (Victoria Street is believed to have been of some inspiration to Rowling for Diagon Alley.) It was around American dinnertime (7pm). They're very proud of their Harry Potter heritage, and they seem to also take liberties with that association. The very front of the cafe, before you even enter, has a banner along the glass outside: "Birthplace of Harry Potter," in curly yellow letters, stylized after the Harry Potter font. Yeah, I'm sure Rowling thought of the idea while sitting in a booth in your cafe... We were seated in about 5 minutes, despite the fact that the place was packed, and I was immediately thrown that they had waiter service. I guess, in my mind, I was seeing a cafe where you ordered at the counter and picked up your food there, but this was more like a restaurant/cafe mashup. Maybe at one time that was how you ordered, but because of the volume of customers, they decided to streamline the ordering service.  Not only is Rowling a known patron, but so is Ian Rankin and Alexander McCall-Smith. It has a huge variety of foods and drinks, from nachos and brushetta, to salad bowls, pizza, lasagna, haggis, bread, potatoes, and a whole lot of other food. Seriously, they are so prepared to cater to everyone.  I gotta admit, though, I could totally see me being a frequent patron if I lived here, gazing out towards the Kirkyard as I sip my coffee. I like elephants, I like coffee, and I like cemeteries. Sounds like a trifecta of inspiration to me. I opted for the coffee with whiskey ("Irish coffee"). It came out in a surprisingly huge glass, when I was just expecting a mug. Delightfully, I could actually taste the whiskey, so it wasn't a drink that was particularly watered down. It was enjoyable, hanging out with my traveling companion, basking in the warmth of a cafe where one of my favorite authors once wrote parts of one of my favorite book series.  And of course I made a stop into the bathrooms. What's so special about them, you ask? People from all over the world come here and mark up the bathroom. It's not just some common graffiti, but you'll find quotes, sketches, notes to Rowling, personal stories, etc. on every conceivable surface. And when I saw every conceivable surface, I am being literal. Light bulbs, hand dryers, soap dispensers, corners of the doors, the ceiling, the glass of wall art (rude!), even the bloody ceiling and ceiling lights! It was pretty impressive to think that someone was so into leaving their mark, they chose to do it on the lightbulb on the ceiling. I legitimately felt a lump forming in my throat, and I can honestly say I don't recall ever almost crying in a bathroom before. It really pulls the fandom together for me. It's one thing to know millions of people have read the books and been touched by them, but it's another thing to see the proof--in hundreds of people's handwriting (likely even thousands). I felt very involved in the whole experience, on a very real, visceral level. And I know how cheesy it sounds to say this, but for the first time in a long time... I felt like I was part of something; part of a community.   To a weirdo like me, I rarely ever feel like I'm a part of anything, but when I went back just now and checked out a video I took, I felt tears in my eyes, MONTHS after my visit. It's absolutely cheesy, I know, but when I felt that way, it was a bit overwhelming, in a good way. So no, maybe the food isn't the best, and the drinks are expensive, but I couldn't help but feel the magic when I was in that bathroom, completely blinding me to any other flaws that the cafe might have. It made me feel a part of something... more. And that's definitely worth 5 stars.

C2u6aKrAxi1Q6Rd0qNUtYw.text: As a huge Harry Potter fan, I was so looking forward to visiting this cafe which they advertise as the Birthplace of Harry Potter and where J.K. Rowling sat writing much of her early novels. I went there at different times in the day and it was always so crowded and a huge line waiting to be seated. The next day I went in morning hours and was seated within couple of minutes. Tried their fruit scones and jam along with tea. Both of them were good but nothing great. I think people come here not because of the coffee shop but because of Harry Potter. So here are my individual ratings Atmosphere: Very touristy and somehow did not give the cafe like feeling near the entrance and the counter area. There is a rear dining room which was more open and full of light. Went there on a rainy day and the view from there was great. Rating - 4 Decor: Was decorated with the elephant theme with many sizes and shapes of elephants. Was interesting and very quirky to see.  Rating - 4  Location: Right across the street from the National Museum of Scotland and in the area of George IV Bridge. Rating - 4 Food selection: Has a mixed menu of starters, soup, some salad options, pizza and a number of desserts Rating - selection wise - 4 but what I tasted 3 Service: Slow. Rating - 2 Bathrooms: This deserves a special mention as the ladies bathroom has a Harry Potter theme again. The walls, mirrors, accessories and surfaces have all HP scribbled over it. Interesting to see Rating:4  Overall I would give it a 3 and a half rating. Skip it if you're not a HP fan. If you are a fan worth a visit and then do not miss the bathrooms.

Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

wC80-IU5PDzbUguW8GKysw.text: I have never met anybody who doesn't like the elephant cafe. It's quirky, it has many elephants and it has a truly wonderful atmosphere. This is qualified by the time of day that you visit. Avoid busy lunch time as the cafe's atmosphere is slightly graught by too many people for too few seats. Musical chairs is not fun when your holding hot drinks from the self service counter.   It's worth stopping for.

aSPulBs3AG6D90TYF3-nGw.text: Just very little to justify the hype. Sometimes even getting seated can be problematic, never mind the lax staff on top of questionably priced products.   The coffee and options on offer are great, but not enough to make me wait when there are decent independent shops around the corner and if I want to wait to be seated of treated by staff who care as much as the average Starbucks Joe, again I'd be around the corner.   The Harry Potter thing is obviously going to be jumped on, but I'll ask JK next time I see her in Starbucks in Bruntsfield

lSGW6XtlNPscwu0DViwaHQ.text: I like this coffee shop - mainly because they're one of the few places that offer cafetiere coffee. It costs about 4 for a big cafetiere full of coffee that will last you a good afternoon while you relax and read a book. The place got so much better when the smoking ban came in. It was unbearable before. As with Elephants and Bagels, the staff are not the friendliest you'll ever find but they're bearable. The cakes and biscuits they do are really tasty and their sandwiches are not too bad.   Check this place out.

XYYG509W9XEx7o0FpGXvLQ.text: The coffe varieties are great and range from great stong kenyan coffees to something a bit smoother and mellow. Cakes are good too but it can be a realt struggle finding a table at peak periods. I wouldn't head here for a leisurely lunch or if you are wanting a private chat because it is a big open room at the back crammed with people who may end up wanting to share your table due to the lack of space. The staff are knowledgeable and friendly and are quick and efficient in their service.  And although JK may have written a bit here, the previous poster is right, she wrote most of the first book in another coffe shop which has since been turned into a Chinese restaurant.

K-rPLosfFJEn49zhrR52Kw.text: The Elephant House is a lovely little coffee shop for whiling away the day with a steaming mug of coffee and one of their delicious cakes.   It's on George IVth bridge, so if you get a window seat, it's a great place for people watching and seeing the world go by. The place is decorated with lots of Elephants (the clues in the name!) so is quite kitsch and cool in comparison to the standard Starbucks and Costas that seem to be on every corner now.   They have a huge selection of teas, coffees and soft drinks so there's something for everyone. Their choice of cakes and pastries/biscuits is a dieters nightmare, as they all taste so good. Particularly famous are the cute shortbread elephants they serve.   All in all it's a very relaxed kind of place. Everyone sits around chatting, reading newspapers etc and you can quite easily lose half the day in there without even realising it!

b9MZlcsaGut2fZRqXVqcjA.text: It is awesome coffee shop, as it is called the Elephant House, and inside there, there are vast array of objects of elephants, in all ranges, and all materials, and everything else in ELEPHANTS it is weird place to be in! Even there is a number of students who do goes there, to take their studies, while having their coffee Even I do sometimes goes in there, to play with their board games which are provided there, and I do spend a lots of time with my friends playing in there. Sometimes it gets quiet, and sometimes it gets busy It varies all the time. Priced at reasonably rate. but loves going in there as it is quite relaxing place to be in.

2v_QKjKOg9YuCgqCEj1EqA.text: Terrible experience. Line was only 10 long but it took 45 mins since service was very slow. Lots of workers but few were helping us customers.

O1lC8g_XpbEps6iuxK97UA.text: well, i suppose there's not much more to be added to those reviews already here - it has undoubtedly one of the best views you'll ever see while sipping a coffee and maybe nibbling a corner of carrot cake. And nice big tables, comfy chairs and a generally sophisticated atmosphere.   Its the sort of place where you come to sit and read a book because you can't just pop over to Paris to sit on the Rive-Gauche and you just need that hit of intellectuality.   Even if they are starting to put up adverts all around town proclaiming the magnificence that they must be because they served coffee when JK Rowling wanted some. I bet she didn't have to wait fifteen minutes for hers. But i must stop myself, before you get the wrong impression, because really i love the place (they've even got internet for those of us who have issues with BT), i just don't want you to be completely duped by all the hype..!   So go for it, go drink a coffee, but remember that you're paying for more than just a coffee when you drink one here...

SlK5RX_nf_4qOOjn7C7ewA.text: I adore this little gem and whenever I have guests from out of town I take them here for a midmorning coffee and snack on the side. It attracts such a mixed crowd: tourists, students working away on their laptops, office workers grabbing a quick coffee or lunch. It all adds to the buzz of this place. There is a big selection of teas and coffees; I usually go for the plain old black perculator coffee. 1.85 for a HUGE cup, an additional 50 for any refill. And it tastes good!   The interior is laidback and relaxed with quirky little elephants everywhere, making me feel like I'm sitting in one of my friend's lounge rooms. There is no pretentiousness here - everyone is welcome. Grab yourself a seat in the back next to the window and you'll find yourself having a stunning view of the Castle. Alternatively, browse through the selection of newspapers and magazines available.   Yes, it gets busy so if you can help it avoid this place during lunch times when all the office workers stream in. But apart from that this place is really worth a visit. Don't forget to grab a pastry. They have a fantastic selection; all of them to die for!

EQp8k2B9ImLMs0faoNUUlw.text: Victim of Harry Potter's success. Too many people. Nice coffee, but no longer is it a place a writer could walk into and write without distractions. Also no evidence of free wifi. Tiny loos if you have children.

sf-Z2_B2RW5fqm1DAxQxmQ.text: This is a cute, cosy cafe in the perfect location just off the Royal Mile. Like everyone else, my friends and I came here for lunch because of the JK Rowling connection after visiting the nearby Spoon Cafe Bistro (also a former cafe where Rowling used to write) and finding the menu too eccentric for us. We were pleased to find that the menu was reasonably priced and really, really good. My chicken tikka baked potato was delicious, as was my smoothie, which I'd been craving all day. The staff was fun and friendly, and the place itself is lovely, with a great view of the castle from the back room (which is said to have inspired Hogwarts). I'll definitely come back if I ever visit Edinburgh again.

cFJHeWqNOoaIImLdJ23ESw.text: Would just like to say thanks for all the kind comments. Please check out our new website at elephanthouse.biz Elephant House

Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. View from the back room of the Elephant House Cafe
Photo of The Elephant House - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Elephant House on a rainy summer morning.

d3FgaHS1Gj3c75_DMjfuMw.text: Harry Potter to me has always been as interesting and welcome in my life as being slapped across the face with a wet fish, so that's not what made me come here yesterday. My boyfriend has a bit of a thing for elephants though (not in that way, or so he says) and I thought it might be nice to bring him here for lunch.  After getting over the disgust that there were no real elephants here, we found ourselves standing in a queue longer than average and scanning round the room hoping someone would get up so we could steal their seat. I was ready to dive for any table. It's really busy in here so I assumed that could only mean it was good.  We eventually got served, I almost killed a man diving for a seat and we settled down to 'experience the magic' of Elephant House. The magic never came, but I did experience a rather nice baked tattie with tuna, and a mug of coffee which was above average too. The prices weren't too bad, or at least, I expected it to be more expensive because of what previous reviewers have said.   Overall, I quite liked The Elephant House. Not being interested in the be-spectacled child one bit maybe took away from some of the excitement of the place, but people forget that authors like Ian Rankin and Alexander McCall-Smith used to come here to write too, which I find much more appealing. Maybe next time I'll take a notepad with me, just incase.

_p7t-inIAamxKt_2VgKcRg.text: I love the back room, it has a great view of the castle. Its a good spot to meet friends, central and with a variety of sandwiches. The coffee and croissants are specially good.

M2bAZPmuBiwdmgcFb4wPvw.text: if it weren't for Harry Potter, it's just a very sub-average bar....

x7BBhFKTZjKbhp6rRXRZHw.text: The famous and official birthplace of Harry Potter. And it sure has a very inspiring setting, with a high ceiling yet cosy main room, views to the castle and Herriot's School(allegedly what Hogwarts is based on) and elephants all over the place, plus a late opening.  Why so few stars? Firstly, because of the Harry Potter claim, this place has become a popular tourist stop as well as over-merchandised. The service is not good for the prices it demands, with the after 6 seated service to be particular slow- all tables seem to be the waiters blind spots. As for the food, well I had a pizza there with a friend and it was basically overpriced soggy cardboard. In another occasion I tried the fajitas- also disappointing. Moreover, the coffee service during the day was particularly unfriendly and impatient. However, I have to admit their French coffee is good. And their late opening hours in a scenic atmosphere are appealing for those who like a quiet evening or read/write. After all, if JK Rowling was inspired maybe it can rub off? The tables are actually quite ideal for this, not to mention the stunning views of the castle from their large windows. If only there were separate stars to give to ambience this place would get 5!   The waiters seem to have many blind spots in the room, but having similar work experience myself, I can completely understand why customers can become invisible. Just make sure you wave enough.  If you do decide to trek here, avoid the lunch hours, as they get to be quite hectic, finding a table is unreliable and the noise level is quite high because of its high ceilings.(and too many small kids) This cafe also has a cousin, Elephants and Bagels which is to my opinion a lot more friendly and less "stuck-up" about famous visitors.

gYUZ5nenbVYrJ1KCW81MXQ.text: We visited this relaxing coffee shop twice on our visit to Edinburgh.  Delicious lattes, yummy sugar cookies shaped like elephants, and awesome ice cream.  We felt completely comfortable, and liked the friendly ambience and leisurely atmosphere.  Great place to unwind after doing all the touristy stuff and feel like you're rubbing shoulders with at least a few locals.

1ERfBTlatHhC63-wzxeHkQ.text: while it could stand on it's own two feet from a marketing perspective, the elephant house has definitely chosen the celebrity route actively promoting their connection with j k rowling, ian rankin and alexander mccall-smith. it's unremarkable not bad though, a low 'good'. too hot for our liking but not scalding. the cappuccino and flat white we tried were definitely made with care by a barista who knew their craft but there were no distinguishing features. if you're serious about your coffee, you can do better in edinburgh. if you're not in a hurry, this is a nice spot to while away a few hours. edinburghcoffeelovers.bl... twitter: @edinburghcoffee

7fw9bgh-fVBA3ens5j8ypw.text: JK might've written bits of HP here, but I'm sure I read an interview in which she gave that honour to a completely different cafe on Nicholson Street, now closed.  Elephant House have certainly staked their claim in letters writ large though, which means you can't walk past this cafe without ending up in someone's holiday snaps. It also means it's very busy at lunchtime. The sign says get your food before bagsying a table, but you're unlikely to be sitting while you eat unless you have an accomplice to throw your coats onto a couple of chairs while you're in the queue. The food is quite good, I think. I've had some delicious paninis there and some very nice pastries. And not that expensive in my opinion. Service is usually quite fast - they have to be given the popularity of the place, and you can get stuff to take away too. If you have elephant phobia then steer clear, the predominant theme in this cafe's decor is elephant. And yes, if you can get a window seat the views are lovely.

Vavd-Sayq21lbGcVG_R3BQ.text: A real gem of a coffee shop, a great place to snuggle up with a hot chocolate on a cold day. Frequented by a wide range of people, the staff are friendly and the atmosphere relaxed, and there are elephants dotted around the place to keep children and adults alike amused. There is a delicious selection of cakes, soup and other homemade goodies, making it a great place for lunch. My only reservation would be that occasionally the food can take a while to arrive, especially when it is busy. Otherwise a great place to meet friends or to sit nursing a drink and a cake (or a shortbread elephant) over a good book or newspaper.

BaeSOfBeUotLVQUmWOg3Jg.text: Every Harry Potter fan's dream come True. You get to sit where JK sat to write the books we love! It was a dream, and the view out the window is amazing!   I went during the afternoon and it wasn't very crowded, I imagine most of the lower reviews are because it can get busy. But it's not just ANY coffee shop, it's famous so it is to be expected.  My coffee and tea were delicious and my waitress was very kind! I went two different times in the same day!

pGS4Df8nlWZd34YX6BHiUw.text: Order placed. A coke. 1 wine. 1 cider. Meat pie. Fritters. :25 min later NOT A  SINGLE ITEM HAD BEEN SENT TO OUR TABLE. We asked 3 servers for any drink item ordered. NOTHING CAME... ever. At :30 min we walked out. Extremely horrible service. Yes it's touristy.  Tables around us ordered 4-6 coffee drinks. We just wanted 1 wine and 1 cider. Go for a coffee and pie. Expect nothing.

anurzHuekzMZYmS0i8P-Vw.text: Extremely disappointed. We were excited to go here after a long day of class events. It was about 9:15 at night and their website said they closed at 10. We walked in and the woman said that they were closing and weren't serving. Like okay, that's understandable. So we decided to just get a T-shirt for the Harry Potter birthplace and she said that she had already shut down the register. (It wasn't even 9:30).   She was extremely rude and we left and probably won't return. We heard that the food sucked anyway. We were so excited to try it and she totally crushed our spirits.   I'm okay with never going back

QDSP5pmRSrKXEySUlSMulQ.text: I happened upon this place while walking around Edinburgh, and I'm glad I did. It is the genesis of Harry Potter, where JKR began writing the series. You can purchase memorabilia, tea, coffee, etc. or sit in and eat. I had a lovely slice of Victoria Sponge cake that was heavenly along with Fleur's Delight, hot chocolate with Bailey's. You must wander into the bathroom. It's a bit dingy, but there are written tributes to Harry Potter and Rowling coveting the walls.
